Technical Assistance Report 
Project Number: 53023-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
December 2019 
People’s Republic of China: Strengthening the Rural 
Health System in Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous 
Region 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information 
Policy.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  provide  research-based 
solutions in the health sector to support inclusive growth in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). 
It will (i) address institutional challenges, and (ii) promote digital technology and eventually 
generate regional public goods. The TA will reduce the rural–urban disparity in health service 
delivery, and support the achievement of Sustainable Development Goal 3 (to ensure healthy 
lives and promote well-being for all at all ages) and attainment of universal health coverage. 
 
2.  The TA is included in the country operations business plan for the PRC, 2019–2021 of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB).1 It is in line with ADB’s country partnership strategy for the PRC, 
2016–2020 and Operational Plan for Health, 2015–2020.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The Government of the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region (GZAR) is committed to the 
PRC’s national rural revitalization strategy as it aims to reinvigorate rural areas to reduce poverty, 
promote equity, improve rural development, and support green and inclusive growth. Improving 
access to health services is critical to achieving this goal, particularly in rural areas. 
 
4.  The PRC’s health sector has undergone a series of reforms since 2009. These included 
shifting resources to primary health care (PHC), which has supported the PRC’s high level of 
health  coverage  and  the  New  Rural  Cooperative  Medical  Scheme,  which  has  become  a 
nationwide comprehensive insurance scheme providing outpatient benefits that target the rural 
population.3 The Healthy China 2030 plan—a national strategy approved by the State Council—
further guides all provinces and regions, including GZAR, to prioritize improvement of rural PHC 
quality, through the use of innovations and health system efficiencies, to reduce the burden on 
hospitals and secondary health facilities.4 However, there is still a significant gap across the PRC 
in terms of health care service quality between urban and rural areas. The quality of clinical 
processes is often left to the discretion of providers, while the quality of health care services is 
highly dependent on provider capacity.5 Providers in urban areas typically have more resources 
and capacity than those in rural areas. GZAR has a rural population of 3 million people in 54 poor 
counties,  and  faces  considerable  challenges  in  improving  rural  health  care  quality,  and  in 
implementing Healthy GZAR 2030.6 
 
1  ADB. 2019. Country Operations Business Plan: People’s Republic of China, 2019–2021. Manila. The initial TA title 
was Study on Health Sector but was adjusted to better reflect the scope of the TA. The TA first appeared in the 
business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 7 November 2019. 
2  ADB. 2016. Country Partnership Strategy: People's Republic of China, 2016–2020—Transforming Partnership: 
People's Republic of China and Asian Development Bank. Manila; and ADB. 2015. Health in Asia and the Pacific: 
Operational Plan for Health, 2015–2020. Manila. 
3  World Health Organization. 2018. Universal Health Coverage and Sustainable Development Goals Country Profile 
2018—China. Geneva. The PRC’s progress towards universal health coverage is as follows: a universal health 
coverage index of 76 out of 100 for coverage of essential services, and 4.8% with respect to financial risk protection 
(the proportion of population with out-of-pocket health spending exceeding 25% of the household's budget or 
income). However, there are gaps in financial risk protection by place of residence and economic status in the PRC. 
4  Government of the PRC, State Council. 2016. The Healthy China 2030. Beijing. 
5  For example, in the PRC, 45% of assistant physicians working in large city hospitals have bachelor’s degrees or 
higher education levels, while at the community level, about 75% of doctors at township and community health 
centers have only vocational high school or 2-year college medical degrees. Most village doctors are former “barefoot 
doctors” who only have a vocational high school medical education. 
6  GZAR. 2017. Advancing Healthy Guangxi Development 2030. Nanning.

2 
5. In addition to gaps in quality between urban and rural health services, GZAR also faces
health risks stemming from the significant volume of cross border trade with and migration from
Viet Nam.7 Controlling outbreaks and cross border health threats can be a major challenge; in
GZAR, animal trade and human migration have the potential to spread communicable diseases
across borders. PHC service providers are the first point of contact for early disease detection,
treatment, and surveillance. Ensuring high-quality PHC services, especially in rural border areas,
can control potential epidemics and protect the health of the population, including vulnerable
groups such as internal and cross border migrants. PHC facilities should be strengthened,
particularly in rural underserved areas,  by improving the quality and capacity of the facilities, as
these are the closest diagnostic facilities on the ground and serve as important surveillance points.
6. GZAR provides free basic public health services to migrants, focusing mainly on maternal
and child health and family planning services. Services include immunization, prenatal and
postnatal checkups for pregnant women, prevention and control of communicable diseases, and
family planning and health education. While basic health care needs are covered, services related
to  noncommunicable  diseases  (NCDs)  and  other  clinical  services,  occupational  health,
rehabilitation, and palliative care (i.e., inpatient and outpatient services) are not covered for
migrants. Such services should be extended to migrants to reduce inequality and improve the
overall health of the migrant population.
7. In addition, GZAR is facing the PRC’s broader national challenge of a rapidly aging elderly
population. Longer life expectancies are increasing the susceptibility of the elderly to costly
prolonged medical issues, particularly NCDs. NCD cases among Chinese people above the age
of 40 are predicted to triple over the next 2 decades, while 35% of the PRC’s population will be
above 60 years of age by 2050.8 Increasing health care services for major NCDs (asthma, cancer,
chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, diabetes, heart disease, hypertension, and stroke) require
integration of primary care settings using innovative and cost-effective interventions. ADB has
increasingly  strengthened  its  intervention  for  elderly  care  in  GZAR  since  2015.9 A  project
approved in September 2019 aims to help GZAR develop a proper integrated health referral
system between medical institutions such as hospitals and elderly care institutions, and improve
the quality and quantity of elderly care institutions to provide a range of care needs.10 This effort
must be expanded to rural primary health service providers, as they are the first level health care
providers in the rural areas.
8. Although the government has actively promoted the use of digital technology to improve
health service delivery and management following the Healthy China 2030 plan, an urban–rural
gap remains in terms of the actual use of digital technology in urban and rural health systems.
Large hospitals in urban areas are using digital technology to efficiently deliver services and
manage  overcrowding  by  queuing  patients  through  online  appointment  systems,  electronic
notification of examination results, digital payment systems, and electronic medical records
systems. Nevertheless, the use of digital technology in rural health facilities is lagging behind.
7  GZAR is one of 10 provinces in the PRC with a rural poverty rate above 7% and one of six provinces with over 
3 million rural poor (as of 2016). This is partly due to low soil fertility associated with karst topography (limestone 
landscapes with sinkholes, underground streams, and caverns) and low levels of infrastructure and connectivity to 
other regions. 
8  Institute of Health Metrics and Evaluation. China: Global Burden of Disease. 
9  ADB. PRC: Guangxi Nanning Vocational Education Development Project; ADB. PRC: Strategic Elderly Care 
Services Development in Yichang; ADB. PRC: Public–Private Partnerships Demonstration Program to Transform 
Delivery of Elderly Care Services in Yichang, Hubei; ADB. PRC: Hebei Elderly Care Development Project; and ADB. 
PRC: Hubei Yichang Comprehensive Elderly Care Demonstration Project.  
10 ADB. PRC: Demonstration of Guangxi Elderly Care and Health Care Integration and Public–Private Partnership 
Project.

3 
Online systems to improve family doctor services and remote diagnosis have been designed, but 
are not fully functional, as rural PHC providers use the system only to settle health insurance 
claims. 
9. To respond to current gaps in rural health service delivery including the weak adoption of
digital technology, rapidly changing needs of the vulnerable rural population, and increasing
health risks related to cross border trade and migration; assessments of GZAR’s rural health
system will be conducted. The TA outputs will help determine interventions that would strengthen
GZAR’s rural health system.
III. THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
A. Impact and Outcome
10. The TA is aligned with the following impact: rural health system in GZAR strengthened
(footnote 6). The TA will have the following outcome: GZAR’s rural primary health system planning
and management improved.11
B. Outputs, Methods, and Activities
11. Output 1: Health services in rural areas assessed. Output 1 will support an assessment
of the rural PHC system, including a review of its capacity, institutional mechanisms, and quality
of services. Current practices of rural PHC providers to support NCD patients, particularly the
elderly and migrants, will be analyzed. The output will also assess the current system, actions of
PHC providers in terms of pandemic response, incentive mechanism of health workers in rural
areas, and quality of services provided to migrants. The TA will support an in-depth assessment
of quality improvement mechanisms that considers the circumstances of male and female patients,
especially in terms of service delivery by rural PHC facilities.
12. Output 2: Application of digital technology for health care services assessed.
Output 2 will assess the use of digital technology to improve access to and the quality of PHC
services in areas where these services are weak. Online platforms that aggregate a database of
physicians from specialty hospitals in GZAR will be explored and assessed. A proposal for an
improved mechanism using digital technology and telemedicine for diagnostic and consultative
support to rural doctors will be developed. The output will assess the use of digital technology to
improve the system and institutional mechanisms that can support better service quality for males,
females, and the elderly.
13. Output 3: Knowledge on improved rural primary health care expanded. Output 3 will
be a knowledge product on rural PHC in GZAR that will build on the work done under outputs 1
and 2. The knowledge product should include a thorough situational analysis of current rural PHC
services in GZAR, including any gaps, and propose methods to improve the overall health system.
The  knowledge  product  should  be  a  substantial  document  that  will  be  published following
agreement between the government and ADB. A TA final workshop which will launch the
knowledge product will be held to discuss and disseminate TA findings and recommendations
with officials from GZAR and at least three other selected provinces.
11 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
C. Cost and Financing
14. The TA is estimated to cost $440,000, of which $400,000 will be financed on a grant basis
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items
are listed in Appendix 2.
15. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of office accommodation,
communication facilities for consultants, counterpart staff, and other in-kind contributions.
D. Implementation Arrangements
16. ADB will administer the TA, which is to be implemented from December 2019 to March
2021. The executing agency will be the GZAR Health Commission. A TA steering committee will
be formed and will be led by the GZAR Project Management Office in Guangxi Development and
Reform Commission; and members will include the GZAR departments of finance, agriculture and
rural affairs, and the GZAR Health Commission.
17. The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  December 2019–June 2021 
Executing agency  Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region Health Commission 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB 
Individual: Individual  International expertise  $90,000 
consultant selection  (4 person-months) 
Individual: Individual  National expertise  $155,000 
consultant selection  (18 person-months) 
Procurement  To be procured by executing agency 
Shopping  1 contract  $2,000 
Disbursement  The TA resources will be disbursed following ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
Asset turnover upon TA completion  The equipment will be handed over to the executing agency upon the 
completion of TA activities. 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, TA = technical assistance. 
Source: ADB. 
18. Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions
and/or  staff  instructions. 12 To  deliver  the  expected  outputs,  a  total  of  4  person-months
(international) and 18 person-months (national) of consulting inputs are required with expertise in
health care quality assurance; health information, communication, and technology; and health
systems.
IV. THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION
19. The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to the
Government of the People’s Republic of China for Strengthening the Rural Health System in
Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
12 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

Key Activities with Milestones 
1. Health services in rural areas assessed
1.1  Conduct desk review on good practices of rural PHC services, and tools for the field survey with use
of gender lens developed by Q2 2020. 
1.2  Undertake field survey to collect sex-disaggregated data conducted by Q3 2020. 
1.3  Organize data validation workshop for data analysis (sex-disaggregated) by Q3 2020. 
2. Application of digital technology for health care services assessed
2.1  Review good practices on the application of digital technology in the health services for rural areas
by Q3 2020. 
2.2  Undertake field survey to collect sex-disaggregated data conducted by Q3 2020. 
2.3  Organize data validation workshop for data analysis by Q3 2020. 
3. Knowledge on improved rural primary health care expanded
3.1  Develop and agree on outline of knowledge product by the executing agency and ADB by Q3 2020.
3.2  Develop draft knowledge product by consultants by Q3 2020.
3.3  Organize the TA final workshop to share the knowledge product with participants by Q2 2021.
